A clutter of parchment sheets, scrolls, and a few books are spread on a table/desk. 

Clumps of dried vegetable matter, bunches of herbs, bones, skulls, and bottles of fluids fill a wall case, hung from the ceiling, etc. 

Robes, cloaks, and capes of various sorts and colors are hanging from pegs near the entry, and a large black staff leans against the wall there (it is just a staff, not magical at all, except that a Nystul's Magic Aura was cast upon it). 

A box under the pallet holds three daggers and a score of darts plus various sundry dungeoneering equipment items including six vials of holy water, a silver holy symbol, a wand with a continual light spell cast upon it (kept in an ivory tube lined with black velvet), and a silver knife. 

A flat chest fastened amidst the rafters to appear to be part of the flooring overhead holds the magic-user's wealth: 51,000 gold pieces' worth of gems, 17,500 gold pieces' worth of gems, and 10010 gold pieces' worth of gems. 

A locked iron coffer holds 200 gold pieces, a ring set with an emerald (3,000 gp value), and a scroll of seven spells which Burne is debating whether to use to expand his spellbook or to save for one emergency. 

The scroll contains: mirror image, pyrotechnics, web, read languages, suggestion, ice storm, and rock to mud.

His spellbook is camouflaged to appear as the seat of the only armchair in the room.

events.name: 3.2 Gundigoot's Chambre
events.description: In addition to bed, dresser, and armoire, Ostler Gundigoot and his wife have a small side room where accounts are kept and the riches stored. A small secret compartment in the north wall holds a locked iron box. Inside are 6 pieces of jewelry (1,000 x 2, 2,000, 3,000, 4,000, and 5,000), a sack of 100 pp., and a sack of 400 gp. A ladder leads to the loft over the small portion of the place, and a concealed door from there leads to the attic of the inn proper. If there is anyone of a highly suspicious nature, Gundigoot will get the Druid of the Grove and spy upon the room concerned by means of small sliding ceiling panels.

events.name: 3.3 Gundigoot's Parlour
events.description:
Tucked away from the bustling common areas, the private parlor stands as a sanctuary reserved for the innkeeper and his family. Here, Ostler Gundigoot finds solace and respite after a day's labor, surrounded by the comforting embrace of his personal haven. The ambiance is distinctly different from the communal spaces, offering an intimate glimpse into the innkeeper's life.

The room exudes an air of cherished privacy, with furnishings that reflect both comfort and functionality. A plush armchair sits near the fireplace, inviting moments of quiet contemplation as the flames dance and flicker. A polished wooden desk adorned with a few choice books and an ornate inkwell bears witness to the innkeeper's responsibilities and correspondence.

The walls are adorned with family portraits, telling the story of generations tied to the inn's legacy. A fine tapestry, passed down through the years, showcases the intricate artistry of the region's craftsmen. The atmosphere here is cozy, hushed, and imbued with a sense of homecoming, inviting the innkeeper and his loved ones to unwind in the warmth of their private sanctuary.

The private parlor is a reflection of Ostler Gundigoot's dedication to his establishment and his desire to preserve a tranquil corner for himself and his family amidst the inn's bustling activity. It is a space where memories are shared, decisions are pondered, and the innkeeper finds his own moments of respite from the daily ebb and flow of life at the Welcome Wench Inn.

events.name: 4.1 Hall
events.description:
The ladderway from below exits here, where an iron door leads to the parapet surmounting the lower tower. 

Another ladderway extends to the upper level of the turret. 

A barrel of 20 javelins is beside the door.

events.name: 4.2 Parapet Level
events.description: As noted previously, the battlement is machicolated, the merlons pierced for archers, and at positions marked A, there are light catapults - one at each - with smooth boulders and small rocks stacked around the base of the turret and near the engines as well. Two guards are on duty here.

events.name: 4.3 Mercenary Captain's Room
events.description: This chamber is sparsely furnished, with a score of arrows and 100 crossbow bolts stored near the door. A small coffer holds 173 platinum pieces and 21,000 gold pieces' worth of gems.

events.name: 4.4 Mercenary Lieutenant's Room
events.description: This room is much the same as the captain's quarters, except that there are 8 quivers full of arrows here and no bolts. He has a purse with 15100 gold pieces' worth of gems, and 50 gold pieces in it.

events.name: 5.1 Turret
events.description: The place is filled with racked pallets for the men-at-arms, who generally sleep here but are otherwise elsewhere.

events.name: 6.1 Turret Roof
events.description: This position is reached by ladder from below. The battlement machicolated, with pierced merlons. There are two scorpions here, along with a long box which holds 30 heavy spears which they fire. Another chest contains rags and pots of oil for the fashioning of flaming missiles to discharge from the scorpions. There is usually a guard here as well.

The circular chamber is screened by a drape of deep green velvet. Inside is a life-sized statue of St. Cuthbert, smiling, great cudgel held high with one hand while the left hand beckons to the doubter and the faithful alike.

Growing ferns and other plants are behind this statue, while to either side are tree stumps for the clerics to officiate from.

An altar is carved from a single piece of bronzewood, adorned with billets, starbursts, and the sacred sign of the crumpled hat.

The walls are wainscoted with carved panels, and a band of holy sayings runs above this woodwork and the painted walls, which depict various marvels performed by St. Cuthbert.

If one of the faithful needs guidance or advice, small sticks are tossed upon the altar, and their conformation enables the cleric to select which holy saying or combination thereof applies.
events.name: Altar & Sanctuary

events.description: Here, Calmert and other under-priests find quarters. The room is large and comfortably furnished, but many cords and ropes with colored wooden beads of appropriate size attached to the ends hang from the center. Above, extending another 30' or so beyond the ceiling overhead, is a collection of bells, chimes, and gongs which must be sounded at certain times of the day (dawn, noon, dusk) and during God's day services in specific melodies and patterns, with Calmert responsible for overseeing this. The room contains two cots, a brazier, and miscellaneous furnishings. One of the large black beads is actually a lump of platinum weighing 10 g.p. - Calmert's personal cache.
events.name: Assisstant Cleric's Chambres
B.1 Cellar Storage Area
events.description: A utilitarian space where the inn's supplies find their temporary abode, the storage area houses an assortment of provisions essential to the inn's daily operation. Boxes and barrels of flour, dried goods, and other necessities are neatly arranged, forming a maze of possibilities for the kitchen staff. Overhead, herbs and bundles of aromatic ingredients dangle from beams, casting a fragrant reminder of the inn's culinary offerings. In the cool, dim lighting of this basement section, the inn's storehouses blend the practicality of organization with the promise of flavorful creations to come.

events.name: B.1 Dungeon
events.description:
3. Horses are sometimes stabled here, and there are heaps of straw, hay, and oats to provide for their needs.

Normally, only the steeds of Burne and Rufus (light and heavy warhorses respectively) are kept here at night.

There are four cells along the southeast wall for prisoner retention.

Each is closed by one oaken door, barred, locked, and chained.

There are also fetters and chains in each cell. The secret door leads to a small natural cave with a spring.

events.name: B.2 Summer Kitchen
events.description: When sweltering heat makes outdoor cooking an uncomfortable endeavor, the summer kitchen provides respite for the inn's culinary endeavors. This space comes to life during scorching seasons, accommodating the preparation of dishes that would otherwise prove challenging in the outdoor fire. In winter, it takes on added responsibilities, ensuring that the inn's guests are treated to warm and hearty meals. The air here is thick with the savory aromas of cooking, while the warmth from the kitchen's activities contrasts with the chill that often settles in other parts of the cellar.

events.name: B.3 Locked Storage (1)
events.description: A cool and dimly lit refuge, this room stands as the inn's perishable sanctuary. Cheeses, butter, meats, and other delicacies find their resting place within, preserved by the room's stony embrace. Barrels of ale, beer, mead, and wine line the walls, their contents waiting to be uncorked and enjoyed by eager patrons. The air carries a hint of earthiness and a whisper of fermentation, a testament to the hidden treasures this room guards.

events.name: B.4 Locked Storage (2)
events.description: Within these walls, the art of winemaking and the pursuit of fine spirits come together. Barrels and tuns, their wooden forms housing the promise of indulgent libations, create a symmetrical pattern along the perimeter. The air is tinged with the deep and rich scents of aged wines and matured brandies. In smaller casks and pottery jars, the variety of tastes is showcased, a testament to the inn's commitment to providing a comprehensive selection for its patrons.

events.name: B.5 Main Cellar
events.description:
A repository of the forgotten and the unused, the main cellar harbors an assortment of discarded furniture, obsolete tools, and cast-aside items. Piles of crates, barrels, and hogsheads nestle among rusty implements and timeworn artifacts. It's a place where history and utility coexist, where an old wheelbarrow rubs shoulders with relics of a bygone era. Dominating one corner is a sizable stack of cordwood, providing a visual reminder of the comfort and warmth the hostel's fireplaces bring to its patrons.

Within this cavernous space, an array of vessels—kegs, barrels, hogsheads, pipes, butts, and tuns—await their next purpose. Among them, three immense casks stand out, each with its own story to tell. Two of these colossal containers still harbor remnants of their former occupants, a rich and lingering residue of wine that clings to the inner walls. The third cask sits empty, a silent witness to past revelries.

An ingenious system of access has been employed here. A section of the side of each cask is hinged, allowing entry into its interior. The mere push of a hidden catch transforms the cask's farend into a makeshift door, swinging inward to reveal another secret. An additional door, hidden within the very wall, becomes accessible when triggered by the insertion of a dagger blade into a well-concealed crock in the fieldstone wall. This intricate arrangement of hidden compartments and passages might serve as a testament to the innkeeper's proclivity for secrecy and surprise.

Beneath the hustle and bustle of the upper floors, the ashpit quietly collects the remnants of fires that blaze in hearths above. Swept down through a chute, the accumulated ash and soot create a granular mound, awaiting the moment of its transformation. Gathered periodically, these once-fiery remnants find new purpose as ingredients for soap-making or as nourishment for the soil

The practicality of the ashpit extends beyond mere disposal. Not only do the ashes from the inn's other fireplaces find their way here, but also a grinder and separator mechanism lies in wait. This place, constructed predominantly from stone and iron, minimizes the risk of fire hazards. The unique inclusion of this area serves as an enticing enigma for curious adventurers, tempting them to uncover hidden treasures or secrets lurking within its depths.

events.name: B.6 Disused Secret Room
events.description:
In times of old, when the malevolent grip of evil held sway across the land, this chamber was a vital hub serving as both a secret meeting place and a covert headquarters for those who dared defy the Temple's oppressive influence.

The room's historical significance is still etched into its very essence, and though its purpose has waned, its legacy remains palpable.

Along the room's perimeter, bunks are meticulously constructed, standing as a testament to the countless warriors who sought refuge and unity within these walls.

Tables and benches, some worn and others sturdier, bear the faint marks of countless conversations spoken in hushed tones.

Preserving the memory of its former occupants, an arsenal of arms is arrayed against the walls, their metallic surfaces protected with a layer of greased defense against the passage of time.

A wide assortment of weaponry stands as a testament to the chamber's past readiness: long swords and short swords, daggers and maces, an assortment of axes, a display of javelins, a rank of spears, and a collection of crossbows—all echoing an era when conflict was not just an idea, but a looming reality.

Crossbow bolts are meticulously stacked, and several operational crossbows are placed in anticipation of an unknown future.

The chamber's weaponry extends to more specialized instruments: a bordiche, glaive-guisarmes, bill-guisarmes, partisans, and even morning stars that evoke an era of determined defense.

In a practical nod to its past function, the chamber's layout facilitates the transport of provisions and bedding from the inn situated above.

A stout wooden chest securely guards a trove of helmets and leather jacks. Adorning the walls, weathered leather shields bear the marks of their history, side by side with bucklers that have seen battles of yore.

The room's most intriguing feature, perhaps, is its ceiling, notably lower than the rest of the cellar, revealing a concealed crawl space between its ceiling and the floor of the inn above. Concealed within the shadows, this crawl space is marked by a flooring of stones overlaid by a layer of soil, contributing to the room's impressive soundproofing capabilities.

In the echoes of time, the secret room may have fallen into disuse, but its stories and ambiance linger on, testifying to the indomitable spirit of those who once sought solace and strategy within its protective confines.
A rustic porch out front. A rocking chair, and a barrel holding a lantern and tankard.
events.name: Cabin Porch

events.description: This is a well-appointed and comfortably furnished room. The mantel of the fireplace lifts up to reveal compartments containing a bronze neck chain set with 61,000 g.p. rubies and an amber cudgel worth 2,500 g.p., depending on how it is separated from the chain. The total value is 10,000 g.p. A +1 mace and a scroll of protection from demons are also stored here. Only Y'dey knows this cache exists. Terjon keeps the cleric's funds (16 pp, 102 g.p., 88 e.p., 317 s.p., and 546 c.p.) in a locked iron coffer beneath his bed. All contributions received go here after taking out 20% for Terjon and 10% for Calmert (usual salary amounts, reduced in cases of large grants and gifts).

From this elevated position, about 15' above the floor below, the chief cleric of the church delivers his weekly and special addresses and sermons.
events.name: Church Balcony
Church Banquet
events.description:
[Banquet Description]{The medieval table is a scene of abundance and rustic charm, set for a hearty feast. A weathered wooden table stretches across the hall, adorned with a worn, linen tablecloth that drapes gracefully to the stone floor. The flickering light of candles in ornate brass holders casts a warm, golden glow over the tableau.

At the center of the table lies a substantial wooden trencher, serving as both plate and platter. Surrounding it are pewter and wooden plates, each bearing a selection of simple but wholesome fare. Roasted fowl, with crispy skin glistening, sits beside a fragrant, herb-stuffed boar. Loaves of crusty bread, some still warm, beckon from a woven basket.

Tankards of frothy ale and goblets of rich red wine are strategically placed, while mead and cider in clay vessels offer additional options. A medley of root vegetables and hearty greens spills from wooden bowls, adding bursts of color to the rustic setting.

The air is redolent with the mingling aromas of roasted meats, savory stews, and freshly baked bread. A bowl of seasonal fruits, displaying vibrant hues of red and gold, serves as a decorative centerpiece.

Seated around the table are wooden benches, their surfaces worn smooth by the countless gatherings of friends and kin.}

Needy laity, acolytes, criminals, and those who have offended the faith are housed or confined in these small rooms (cells). Each cell contains a peg, pallet, and pail. The tiny window is barred, and the heavy iron-bound door is bolted shut from the outside.
events.name: Church Cells

events.description: Polished hardwood floors support simple training equipment — from weighted bags to practice weapons. Mirrored walls reflect the focused efforts of practitioners, while high windows let in streams of natural light, fostering an atmosphere of dedicated physical training within the sacred confines.
events.name: Church Excercise Room

events.description:
This grand chamber serves as the focal point for the faithful who gather to hear the sermon delivered on God's day eve. 

The floor is resplendent with well-polished wood, while wooden pillars reach upwards to support a ceiling that stretches all the way to the roof's apex.

Tinted glass mosaics of varying hues allow multicolored light to filter into the hall, creating an ethereal ambiance.

While benches, pews, and stools are absent from this area, it beckons all who enter to engage in solemn reflection and contemplation.
events.name: Church Hall

events.description: This is where a serving woman and her husband prepare meals and attend to the needs of the churchmen. All regular meals are taken here.

Concealed within a thick book titled "LEGAL AFFAIRS IN VELUNA 213 to 312 CY" is a scroll containing 6 clerical spells (one spell of each level) and an amulet of protection.

The floor, fashioned from light wood, contrasts with the deep blue walls adorned with silver-leaf starbursts.

Spring Morning
events.description:
It is a new [Spring]{Spring is one of the four seasons.} morning. There are *Goblin* raiders nearby.

The air is filled with birdsong and the gentle rustling of new leaves. 

The air is crisp and fresh. Soft sunlight bathes the landscape in a warm glow.

On non-holy days, those entering the church must pass through this room. The lesser clerics bid them be seated on hard benches near the door, away from the padded chairs near the fireplace. Religious tracts and scrolls are provided for perusal at nearby tables, indicating the location of the poor box, which is emptied after each visitor's departure. Those seeking audience with the cleric return within 2-12 minutes. After inquiring about the visitor's business, the cleric may request a contribution for the needy (about 1-10 gp per level of the strongest character in the party), and information is sometimes withheld if the person desired is unavailable, leading to a later visit.

events.description:
There will be 2·5 sway-backed, pottbellied, spavined old plugs out in the yard, as well as a like number of vicious, cowardly mongrel dogs. 

These are for sale at 70% of list price (draft horse, hunting dog). 

The horses are 50% likely to stop every turn to rest, and if pushed by hard riding or heavy load 50% likely to die (check every turn). 

The dogs will bite and snap at handlers at every opportunity, and they will certainly run away (and return to the traders) as soon as they are not tied fast. 

(Naturally, the traders will claim that it is a case of caveat emptor or that the dog is absolutely another which resembles the one purchased only superficially, perhaps adding a spot of dye to alter its appearance.)

events.description:
This room is adequately furnished with two comfortable bunks, a table and chairs, wall shelves and pegs, a chest of drawers, and a pair of lockers for personal gear.

A small locked coffer holds 150 pp, 300 g.p., 500 e.p., and 1000 g.p. gems, 2 potions of invisibility, a speed potion, and a small black scarab with the glyphs \"TZGY\".

The latter item is a pass sign of the Temple of Elemental Evil, but there is only a 20% chance that even a sage would recognize it as such.

A portion of the outer wall is triggered to swing out from the bottom if a small board is slipped sideways.
events.name: Traders' Quarters

events.description:

All livestock prices are 110% of list, with warhorses at 120%.
events.name: Traders' Stables

events.description:
At the Traders' Establishment, a wide range of [SALEABLE GOODS]{If a specific item is not listed below, assume that it can likely be obtained here, catering to the needs of villagers and adventurers alike. Rare or unusual items can be acquired at a price and within a certain timeframe, although they may sometimes be counterfeit or faulty.

However, magic items are never sold here. Quantities are limited according to the stock normally available in a small village.

CLOTHING AND PACKS: Peasant equipment is about 90% of the list price, rounded down; dungeon exploring items are 110%, rounded up.

FOOTWEAR, GLOVES, BELTS: Prices for adventurers will be 125% of the list, and 80% for villagers.

HAND TOOLS: Hammers, adzes, planes, nails, saws, etc. A file sells for 1 s.p. and up; saws cost about the same as a hand axe or hatchet.

LIGHTING EQUIPMENT: Tinder boxes, candles, oil, lamps, wicks, lanterns, etc. 110% of list, rounded up.

FOOD AND HERBS: Packed rations are 120% of list, and herbs are at 150% of cost.

ROPES, CHAINS, AND DUNGEONEERING GEAR INCLUDING WRITING MATERIALS AND RELIGIOUS ITEMS: 110% of list.

POLE ARMS AND SHIELDS: 110% of list.

OTHER WEAPONS, MISSILES, AND ASSOCIATED GEAR: 120% of list.

ARMOR AND HELMETS: Padded, leather, and studded leather are in stock. There will be a 70% chance that a ring mail jack is available, 50% for a suit of scale mail, 30% for chainmail, and 10% for a set of banded mail. These are at 150% of list. Orders will be 200% of list, half in advance. Waiting time is 13-30 days, and fit is not guaranteed (use d6, 1 too small, 6 too large, others fit).

TACK, HARNESS, WHEELBARROWS, DUNGEON CARTS: List price, dungeon carts at 75% of list, one per customer.} is offered.

events.description:
??"Halt! Who goes there? State your business, or face the consequences."

??"Another quiet night on watch. I hope it stays that way."

??"You there! No loitering around the tower after dark. Move along!"

??"I'd trade my post for a warm bed and a hot meal any day."

??"By the gods, these night shifts make me question my life choices."

??"What's that noise? Must be just the wind playing tricks on me again."

??"Oi, you! Keep your torch away from the hay, we don't want a repeat of last week's incident."

??"I swear, if one more owl hoots, I might just join the nocturnal choir."

??"It's a moonlit night, but that doesn't mean I won't stick you with this spear if you cause trouble."

??"Ever feel like the stones of this tower have more exciting tales to tell than we do?"

Brewery

locations.description:
This newly constructed building is the shop and home of the local CARPENTER, his wife, and a YOUNGER BROTHER. 

He also does work for some of the other townspeople and is currently at work on barrel staves. 

As typical, he is too busy to think of adventuring.

Having come to the village about two years ago, this family is considered as "outsiders" and will be until their beards grow gray.

They are followers of St. Cuthbert.
locations.name: Carpenter
Carpenter

locations.description:
A distinctive feature of this house is the leather hide that's tacked onto its front door.

This residence serves as both the home and business establishment of the village's LEATHERWORKER.

Residing with him is his wife and her unarmed brother, a simpleton.

Together, they have three children. The eldest child is a 12-year-old BOY.

The LEATHERWORKER is truly a jack-of-all-trades, engaging in various tasks such as crafting shoes, boots, saddles, harnesses, and even leather garments and armor.

The latter tasks are time-consuming, requiring multiple fittings and boiling processes.

Despite his versatile skills, he holds no interest in any form of adventuring.
locations.name: Leather Shop

locations.description:
A modest cottage where a POTTER is busily engaged in the manufacture of various sorts of dishes and vessels.

However, most of his work goes to passing merchants or the trader.

He has a variety of [earthenware bottles] and [flasks] available for sale. 

The  A crock in the well holds 27 gold pieces, 40 silver pieces, and 610 gold pieces' worth of gems. They are of the faithful of St. Cuthbert.
locations.name: Potter

locations.description:
[Exterior Description.]{A newly-built stone house stands here on the eastward road out of the village. 

Sapling bushes contain the property.}
locations.name: Stonemason

locations.description:
A quaint cottage with a thatch roof.

Concealed in a [false bottom] of his thread box lies a sum of (19 silver pieces).
locations.name: Tailor

locations.description:
This well-maintained dwelling features a wooden sign that showcases a bag of wool and a loom, signifying its purpose. 

Bolts of woolen and flaxen cloth fill the space, hinting at the thriving trade. 

Although the workshop is their main focus, nothing else of particular interest is found within.
locations.name: Weaver

locations.description:
This is the residence and shop of the local Wheel and Wainwright, an ARTISAN.

The main part of the structure is a barn where he builds and repairs carts and wagons.

The ARTISAN, two HELPERS, and a small child live in the side apartment.

His wife is dead, and his helpers are nephews.

These folks are followers of St. Cuthbert. 

The ARTISAN tends to drink too much but is good-hearted.
locations.name: Wheel & Wainwright

locations.description: Insert information about Bingham Farm here.
locations.name: Bingham Farm
Dorsel Dairy Farm

locations.description:
A propserous farmstead sits here, next to the Halvard farm. 

By the stable there is a [Pile of Manure]{Inside a crock in the manure pile are hidden 3x50gp gems, 37pp, and 55gp.}.
locations.name: Eldric's Farm

locations.description:
[Reputation in the Village]{A somewhat reclusive farmer, his spinster daughter, and son dwell here. 

They are not particularly successful at farming, but they are excellent fishers, trappers, and hunters. 

The villagers are not particularly fond of these folks. 

The spinster daughter is only in her twenties and is handsome but bossy.

These people do not follow any religious persuasion, so they are excluded from most village functions. }
locations.name: Falker Farm

locations.description:
[Location Description]{The wood and plaster house is well-kept, and the barn beyond is bulging with feed, grain and hay.

Several fat animals are about.

Beyond this, the farmer does not have anything to trade or sale. There is nothing to interest would-be adventurers here.

Inside the house, of note is the Farmer's matress. Inside this matrress, the farmer has 57pp.

Two large farmdogs bark loudly at the approach of strangers.

*Dog*}
locations.name: Halvard Farm

locations.description:
The house on this well-kept farm stands as a testament to its former inhabitants' prosperity.

The property appears to be thriving, with the stock in the fenced-in yard looking healthy and picturesque.

There is a [Tree]{Buried beneath the tree in the back yard is a large iron pot; it holds 97gp and 421sp.} in the back yard.
locations.name: Kolport Farm

locations.description:
[What services do they offer?]{They grind grain into flour, of course. 

Goodwife Mycroft also does some bread baking for the village.}
locations.name: Miller

locations.description:
Clean but slightly rundown wood and plaster buildings indicate that this farm is not too prosperous. However, the stock around looks quite healthy and plump. 

There is nothing of particular interest to be seen, and these folks have nothing to trade.

[What loot is there hidden?]{In the Front Room there is a "Chest". Old Man Oakshot keeps the following items hidden here: 

#Scale Mail Suit#,
#Medium Shield#,
#Longsword#,
#Light Crossbow#.

In the "house", there is a "cupboard". In the cupboard there is a silver service worth 1,300 gp.

There is a "Barn".Hidden here in a lead-lined oaken chest buried beneath the dirt floor of the barn:

+1 #Chain Mail Suit#
+2 #Medium Shield#,
+1 #Battle Axe#,
6 x 100 gp gems,
10pp, 50gp, 100sp.}
locations.name: Oakshot Farm

locations.description: There is a cottage here, guarded by [Three Dogs]{*Dog*}.
locations.name: Black Jay's Cabin

locations.description:
[Extrnal Description]{This place is the home of a hersman. A stout cottage, with a path leading to grazing fields behind.} 

His wife is dead, but a FULL-GROWN SON and his wife care for the five children.

A COUSIN helps to tend the livestock, and he has brought his two *dog*s along.

These folks are friendly, but they are not interested in adventure and have little interest in the way of goods.
locations.name: Herdsman's House
Woodcutter's Cottage

locations.description:
There are some double fieldstone walls filled with earth here. 

These are the beginnings of a smallish castle, being built around a new tower atop the low mound.

Workers have dug deep trench lines about 10' wide and as deep, down to a hard clay, and it can be seen that they are in the process of mortaring the foundations of the wall which they will build above.

Work has barely begun, but the outlines of bastions, towers, a gatehouse, and a keep can be noted. The keep is atop the second hillock, and considerable excavation has taken place, the earth from this digging going to use in the walls around the whole.

Some dressed stone blocks are visible, evidently having been carted in from elsewhere, as they are not similar to local stone.
locations.name: Castle

locations.description:
You are standing in front of a Church.

This newly-built edifice was raised by the Viscount of Verbobonc in honour of the aid rendered to him by the Archcleric of Veluna in the war against the Temple of Elemental Evil.

It seems to have been built recently, within the last few years. Moss and the stain of time have yet to take effect.

Above its imposing entrance, is engraved the symbol of #St. Cuthbert#: a circle at the centre of a starburst of lines.
locations.name: Church of St. Cuthbert

locations.description:
This is obviously a place of worship.

The trees are neatly pruned, and the grass is well-tended. A carefully placed line of bluish stones sets off the path leading to a rock cairn where flowers, nuts, berries, and garlands of leaves are placed.

A small path leads beyond the shrine to a low-roofed wooden building placed under the great boughs of the central oaks of the copse.
locations.name: Druid's Grove

locations.description:
This structure is some 55' high, a smaller tower rising inside the greater at about 35' above the ground.

Its entrance is accessible only by going up a curving flight of stone stairs which terminate in a landing about 10' above the ground.

The outer door of the tower lowers to form a bridge to the stone landing.

There are numbers of arrow slits around the tower, and it has a parapet around the base to about 6' height.

The lower and upper battlements are machicolated, the merlons being pierced for archery as well. Two men-at-arms watch from its roof.
locations.name: Two-Storied Tower

locations.description:
[Exterior Description.]{This place has an 8' high stone wall and a heavy gate.}

[Family Information.]{It is the residence of the Village Elder, his wife, and four grown sons.

Two of these sons are married, and their wives and three children live here as well.

The Elder is a retired farmer, and his sons now care for the fields and livestock.

All of his sons have horses and are very proud of their status.

There are two servant girls and a hired farmhand quartered in the loft of the stable.}

[Village Elder Information.]{During times of attack, the elder and his family and servitors are all druidic-aligned.

Villagers nearby seek safety in his compound.

He is greatly respected and quite wise.

He has a council composed of the Druid of the Grove, the Chief Cleric of the Church, the Captain of the Militia, the Innkeeper, the Miller, and recently the Magic User Burne and his Fighter associate Rufus.

Once each new moon, he holds a village meeting to hear ideas and complaints, as he is also the justice of the peace.}
locations.name: Village Elder

locations.description:
From the road, a gate stands in the middle of a wall that covers the front of the building and connects between the tavern and next door stable house.

Above the gate, which is wide enough for a wagon to pass through unhindered, there dangles on heavy chains a square wooden sign depicting a buxom woman and a smiling girl holding a flagon of beer.
locations.name: Welcome Wench Inn
Yungdomshuset

locations.description:
Dangling outside this large wooden building, a shield and a lantern hang suspended from chains. The shield's painted depiction combines a sword and a cheese.

This establishment serves as the local trading post.The traders express willingness to [purchase]{They claim to pay 40% to 70% of the stated selling price in good condition, mirroring their policy of selling at 110% of book value or the minimum price. They will begin by asking more first before sealing a deal.} any items the adventurers happen upon, offering a fair price for such acquisitions. 

In the rear area of the building, a variety of animals are available for purchase: mules, draft horses, light riding horses, ponies, and one medium warhorse.

A groom and a man-at-arms are [available for hire]{They demand a daily wage of 2 gold pieces and require that adventurers purchase chain mail suits of armor for them.

Naturally, they prefer to have their agents accompany the party.

If the group opts not to hire their agent, the traders will closely monitor the adventurers' activities through any means possible, including shadowing them if circumstances necessitate, particularly if the party's success is notable. For such missions, the stock of magical devices hidden away will be revealed.} upon request from the traders.
locations.name: Hommlet Trader

locations.description: A sturdy new building with a sign showing three yellow balls, indicating the moneychanger's shop.
locations.name: Jewels & Money Changer

locations.description:
A wooden sign with a depiction of a cart and horse signals that this is the residence and dwelling of the local Carter.

The Carter and his associates are diligent and open to employment opportunities.
locations.name: Teamster

npcs.name: Gremag
npcs.description:
A tall and thin individual with sharp features and protruding eyes. 

He is meticulous and prone to fussing over his business partner Rannos Dovi and customers alike.

npcs.name: Calmert Eldicort
npcs.description: Known for his zeal in obtaining contributions to the church. This honest man is anxious to give a sum to the builders of the castle under construction, and although it would seem otherwise, most of the miscellaneous monies he collects for 'the church' from characters will actually go towards building the castle!

npcs.name: Terjon Applbaum
npcs.description:
Terjon recently became the canon of the church after the Canoness Y'Dey left unexpectedly and has not returned. 

The villagers say that Terjon is not particularly friendly and his sterness is a cause of some speculation. 

Actually, the cleric is not a bad fellow at all, but he is rather displeased at being called to care for the church while Y'Dey is on a quest, for Terjon is desirous of being off adventuring himself, and ONLY the request of the Archcleric of Veluna keeps him at his station.

npcs.name: Nira's Dog 1
npcs.description: Insert information about Nira's Dog 1 here.

npcs.name: Nira's Dog 2
npcs.description: Insert information about Nira's Dog 2 here.

npcs.name: Agnus Oakshot
npcs.description: With wisps of silver hair framing her gentle face, the old woman's eyes sparkled with wisdom and kindness. Time had etched lines on her face like a well-worn map, each wrinkle telling tales of a life well-lived. She moved with a graceful resilience, embodying warmth, resilience, and a quiet strength.

npcs.name: Alfred Anquetil
npcs.description: These men are all neutral chaotic or pure neutrals in alignment. They were brigands for a time but they decided that there was better pay and less risk serving Burne and Rufus, who took them prisoner and then spared them. Loyalty is good, and morale is high. They have had some action against other marauders, get top money, and spend an ample amount of off-duty time drinking and carousing at the Inn.

npcs.name: Anders Dorsel
npcs.description: A teenaged boy.

npcs.description: Barrington Poleon's Child

npcs.description: The stonemason's apprentice.

npcs.name: Barrington Poleon
npcs.description: The Village Elder's Son.

npcs.name: Berry Treefallen
npcs.description: The woodcutter's teenage daughter, blossoming into womanhood, had an air of quiet strength. Her eyes, framed by auburn locks, held a mix of youthful curiosity and emerging wisdom. While her hands were yet to bear the marks of labor, there was a quiet resolve in her spirit, a promise of resilience inherited from her parents.

npcs.name: Blossom Treefallen
npcs.description: The woodcutter's wife, younger than her weathered husband, exuded a quiet resilience. Her hands, though not as calloused, bore the traces of shared toil. With a grace that belied her strength, she moved through the homestead, her eyes reflecting a deep love for her family and a silent understanding of the challenges faced by the man she chose to stand beside.

npcs.name: Boyan Penchev
npcs.description: These men are all neutral chaotic or pure neutrals in alignment. They were brigands for a time but they decided that there was better pay and less risk serving Burne and Rufus, who took them prisoner and then spared them. Loyalty is good, and morale is high. They have had some action against other marauders, get top money, and spend an ample amount of off-duty time drinking and carousing at the Inn.

npcs.name: Brank Treefallen
npcs.description:
The woodcutter's boy, a sturdy lad with tousled hair and curious eyes, emulated his father's resilience. 

Calloused fingers, hinting at a youthful apprenticeship, gripped a small axe. Despite the innocence in his gaze, there was a determination to learn the craft, embodying the legacy of a family rooted in the rhythmic symphony of the forest.

npcs.name: Brigham Poleon
npcs.description: The Village Elder's Son.

npcs.name: Burbank Poleon
npcs.description: These men are all neutral chaotic or pure neutrals in alignment. They were brigands for a time but they decided that there was better pay and less risk serving Burne and Rufus, who took them prisoner and then spared them. Loyalty is good, and morale is high. They have had some action against other marauders, get top money, and spend an ample amount of off-duty time drinking and carousing at the Inn.

npcs.name: Camden Cloy
npcs.description:
Despite not being part of the village militia, this individual possesses remarkable skills.

He excels in throwing knives and using a crossbow, both of which he has at his disposal. 

These abilities are honed to the level of a 7th-level Fighter, with a bonus of +2 damage upon landing a hit.

While his constitution is limited to only 2 hit points, he recently moved to the village and is not yet a member of the Hommlet Company due to his hesitance. An unassuming bachelor of around thirty years. The tailor is an adherent of St. Cuthbert, aligning his values with this faith. He is known for his mild manner and is an expert in creating and repairing garments.

npcs.name: Carl Poleon
npcs.description: They are the Village Elder's Son.

npcs.name: Carmine
npcs.description: In the tavern's haze, the serving wench, a spirited mélange of allure and chaos, moved with untamed grace. Her laughter echoed amid ale-soaked conversations, captivating hearts with a bewitching gaze. Unfettered by societal norms, she carried the tales of both the alehouse and her own enigmatic journey, a tapestry of unrestrained existence.

npcs.name: Darnal
npcs.description: Insert information about Darnal here.

npcs.name: Eldric Halvard Sr.
npcs.description: Worn by life's hardships, the grumpy, bankrupt farmer trudged through his dilapidated land, haunted by financial ruin. Lines etched deep by disappointment framed his weathered face, and the scent of failure lingered. Alcohol became his solace, a bitter escape from a harvest of shattered dreams and barren fields.

npcs.name: Emilie Hansen
npcs.description: Henrik's Wife.

npcs.name: Eugene Kolport
npcs.description: They are druidical in religion.

npcs.name: Evan Pine
npcs.description: Carpenter's Younger Brother

npcs.description:
4 Hit Points. 

#Leather Suit#,
#Medium Shield#,
#Battle Axe#, 
#Dagger#.

npcs.name: Florence
npcs.description: In the bustling inn, the timid serving wench blended into shadows, her movements delicate and unobtrusive. Soft-spoken, she poured ale with a hesitant smile, navigating trays through the lively chaos. Yet, beneath timidity, a quiet resilience flickered, as she weaved through the tumult, an unseen presence in the tapestry of the tavern.

npcs.name: Frank
npcs.description: The weaver's apprentice.

npcs.description: Barrington Poleon's Child

npcs.name: Helga Halvard
npcs.description:
She is rosy-cheeked. Her voice is raspy, and she is always out of breathe. She is friendly, caring and overly concerned with other peoples' problems. 

She is known around as a busy-body, and a gossip. They are druidical in religion.

npcs.description:
Another of the newcomers to Hommlet recently built this stone home.

The stonemason, his wife, two children, and three apprentices are at work on the new castle being constructed on the low hill blocks to the southeast (31. area).

He is well-regarded in the village.

These folks are #Druidical#, and the Master Mason has offered to help with the working of several large monoliths for the Grove after the castle is finished.

This newcomer is a fervent advocate of St. Cuthbert and is known for his honesty.

npcs.name: Vollrath
npcs.description: Vollrath is the Cabinet Makers apprentice. He does all of the rough work in the workshop.

npcs.name: Gnarl Treefallen
npcs.description:
The woodcutter, a father and husband, stood weathered and robust, his face etched with lines earned from years of wielding an axe against ancient trees. Strong sinews and hands stained with the earth's hues mirrored a life of hard toil. 

His eyes, a mix of determination and paternal warmth, revealed a silent dedication to family and the timeless dance with the forest.

He is of druidical religion, and he reports anything unusual to the Druid of the Grove.

npcs.name: Ostler Gundigoot
npcs.description:
The portly, bald innkeeper, a jovial figure in apron and vest, commands the bustling tavern with a hearty presence. Round spectacles perch on a bulbous nose above a welcoming smile. His rotund frame exudes warmth, a beacon for weary travelers seeking solace and sustenance in the comforting embrace of his establishment.

Gundigoot keeps about 100 gp equivalent in his apron pockets.

npcs.name: Theodosii Sverdlov
npcs.description: These men are all neutral chaotic or pure neutrals in alignment. They were brigands for a time but they decided that there was better pay and less risk serving Burne and Rufus, who took them prisoner and then spared them. Loyalty is good, and morale is high. They have had some action against other marauders, get top money, and spend an ample amount of off-duty time drinking and carousing at the Inn.

npcs.name: Yegor Neville
npcs.description: These men are all neutral chaotic or pure neutrals in alignment. They were brigands for a time but they decided that there was better pay and less risk serving Burne and Rufus, who took them prisoner and then spared them. Loyalty is good, and morale is high. They have had some action against other marauders, get top money, and spend an ample amount of off-duty time drinking and carousing at the Inn.

npcs.name: Zert
npcs.description:
Ostensibley awaiting the return of a caravan from the south, he is actually a spy for the #Temple of Elemental Evil#.

He can drink great quantities without becoming drunk (200% normal capacity). 

He will happily go with adventurers for an equal share of treasure, and he will as readily betray them and then take their goods. 

He is not aware that the traders are also evil minions of the temple, although they know who and what Zert is.

npcs.name: Black Jay
npcs.description:
He is middle-aged, and unkempt. He rarely washes and has brown teeth. 

Due to to the tragic loss of his wife and children during his time away in the wars, he refuses to engage in adventuring. Black Jay is quite reclusive and unfriendly to company and strangers, often voicing his dislike to anyone who enters his property. 

He is friendly with the Elves to the Northwest.

npcs.name: Gaffar
npcs.description: He is Mira Medlub's bodyguard.

npcs.name: Gaffar Shadiq
npcs.description: Gaffar Shadiq, the vigilant Moneychanger Guard, stands firm as Mira Medlub's dedicated protector at the quiet Moneychanger's Shop. With a stoic demeanor and watchful eyes, he ensures the security of both the shop's wealth and his employer, a steadfast guardian in the tranquil heart of financial dealings.

npcs.name: Old Man Oakshot
npcs.description: The elderly farmer is a retired fighter. He is captain of the militia, but he will say nothing of it.

npcs.name: Spas Kostomarov
npcs.description: These men are all neutral chaotic or pure neutrals in alignment. They were brigands for a time but they decided that there was better pay and less risk serving Burne and Rufus, who took them prisoner and then spared them. Loyalty is good, and morale is high. npcs.description: These men are all neutral chaotic or pure neutrals in alignment. They were brigands for a time but they decided that there was better pay and less risk serving Burne and Rufus, who took them prisoner and then spared them. Loyalty is good, and morale is high. They have had some action against other marauders, get top money, and spend an ample amount of off-duty time drinking and carousing at the Inn.

npcs.name: Rufus
npcs.description:
Rufus leads a squad of Men-at-Arms and has been appointed as the overall commander of the village troops as well.

Rufus and Burne came to Hommlet some three years ago, had some considerable success in adventuring, including the defeat of a large bandit force which had plagued #Verbobonc#, and it is rumored that they gained considerable treasure in killing a *Green Dragon* which preyed in the #Kron Hills# to the west.

He is friends with all the important folk in the village.

npcs.name: Granny Halvard
npcs.description: An old woman, with shocked white hair unkempt. It is said birds nest within it.

npcs.name: Jeremy Spinish
npcs.description:
Aspiring Druid, a teenage potboy in the local tavern. Wild, untamed curls frame earnest eyes that flicker with nature's secrets. Amid ale spills and raucous laughter, he silently nurtures a bond with the natural world, dreams of verdant groves while scrubbing tankards, his youthful spirit intertwined with the tavern's rustic tapestry.

He doubles as a courier for the #Druid of the Grove#, delivering messages of interest.

npcs.name: Spugnoir
npcs.description:
This chap came into the village with a merchant wagon, and he is staying in hopes of gathering spells, for he knows only detect magic, read magic, and sleep.

He has a large trunk holds his magical paraphernalia, clothing, and a fair assortment of dungeon exploration materials, for he plans to quietly search the ruined moathouse, having learned that a warlock was housed there.

His funds currently amount to 11 pp, 9 gp, and 7 sp in his wallet, and 350gp X3 gems he has secreted in the hem of his cloak.

If approached and offered all scrolls found, he will go with a party.

Otherwise, he will attempt to shadow the group and get what he can.

npcs.name: Brother Smyth
npcs.description:
#Studded Leather Suit#,
#Iron Hammer#,
#Quarterstaff#.

He lives here alone. 

The blacksmith is a sturdy and compact figure, although short, exuding strength and likability. He's known for his diligent and forthright work ethic.

The Smith possesses a wide range of metalworking skills, capable of crafting iron and steel weapon heads, tools, and shield work.

While he humbly acknowledges his limitations in fine armoring, his expertise in other forms of metalwork is impressive.

Referred to as "Brother Smyth" he holds the role of assistant to the Druid of the Grove.

Despite his dedication as a devoted cleric, his ranking within the druidic order is hindered by his occupation.

He's unlikely to attain a high position due to this role, yet he serves wholeheartedly.

In the absence of the head druid, Brother Smyth takes on the role of spiritual advisor to the faithful.

The majority of his wealth is dedicated to charitable endeavors for the less fortunate. 

Despite his commitment, he adamantly avoids leaving his forge and hearth for the pursuit of adventuring.

npcs.name: Jarco Ashstaff
npcs.description:
A call will bring forth the druid JORCO ASHSTAFF.

All comers to the Grove are expected to make offerings—then and there, and the druid will so state.

If the visitors are not druidic, they are expected to give several gold pieces to JORCO as donations towards the needy of Hommlet.

The DRUID will listen to requests for assistance from those who contribute.

JORCO is an AGENT of the DRUIDS OF GNARTY WOOD, sent to Hommlet for help.

If the [Temple of Elemental Evil] is totally destroyed and to help repress any rise of evil of this sort.

He will give aid by SPELLS but not accompany a party. If the group is a suspicious one, JORCO will follow at a distance to see what goes on.

He has a HUGE BLACK BEAR which is always nearby but out of sight 95% of the time.

npcs.name: Burne
npcs.description:
Burne is clever and a trifle on the greedy side. All services rendered will be paid for handsomely! 

He is a follower of #St. Cuthbert# and very conscious of his duty to protect the village and to watch for evil.

So, any adventuring will be calculated to accomplish those ends and pay him a third of the treasure gained as well. 

He is not likely to risk his life or be duped. Burne is on the young side for a magic-user, average in appearance and dress, and will often frequent the Welcome Wench Inn. 

It is well known that these two men are tough and very cautious but willing to give some aid to adventurers for a price.

Rufus and Burne came to Hommlet some three years ago, had some considerable success in adventuring, including the defeat of a large bandit force which had plagued #Verbobonc#, and it is rumored that they gained considerable treasure in killing a *Green Dragon* which preyed in the #Kron Hills# to the west.

He is friends with all the important folk in the village.

npcs.name: Mariza Falker
npcs.description:
A stubborn, handsome woman of thirty, her features etched by the outdoors. Sun-bronzed and rugged, with determined hazel eyes. A trapper, fisher, and hunter, she thrived in the wild, her unyielding spirit mirroring the untamed landscapes she called home, as familial bonds anchored her in a life of rustic beauty and strength.

She is Hristo Falker's Daughter

npcs.name: Elmo Oakshot
npcs.description:
Elmo is strong, but not too quick, and he is overfond of brew. 

He carries a #+2 Dagger# at all times. If asked about it, he will exclaim, "my brudder Otis gave it to me!" 

Elmo's speech is slow and halting. 

He often appears tipsy and jovial, but he is not. Elmo is an agent of the Viscount of Verbobonc, and he frequents the Welcome Wench Inn in order to observe all newcomers and insinuate himself in their expeditions.

Thus Elmo will be appear to be interested in getting money (to be used for later ale purchases obviously) in exchange for services as a man-at-arms.

He will gladly go with any who ask providing they furnish him with armour and a "big axe". 

If so employed, he will wear his own #Chain Mail Suit# in place of, or under, that purchased and use his magic #Battle Axe# as well. 

If anything befalls Elmo, his brother Otis will eventually hear of it and seek redress.

npcs.name: Otis Oakshot
npcs.description: Tall and rugged, Otis is dressed for adventure, with well-worn but serviceable gear. His confident stance reveals his experience.

npcs.name: Darnal Abergowl
npcs.description: In his twenties, the farmhand bore a sunburned visage, a testament to relentless labor under the unforgiving sun. Calloused hands betrayed a resentment rooted in unfulfilled aspirations, a simmering discontent masked by a facade of dutiful diligence. His gaze hinted at dreams deferred, a spirit yearning for a life beyond the confines of the fields.

npcs.name: Nira Melub
npcs.description:
He has 12 Hit Points. 

He will happily exchange coins or metal for other exchange media, charging only 10% of the value. 

Nira also deals in gems and jewelry (paying from 50% to 80% actual value), buying, selling (102% to 120% above actual value), and even making it (cost is materials' valuedoubled, which is the new value of the jewelry also).

He asks no questions and is always obliging and polite.

Melub is truly neutral. He has no interest in what happens, though he dislikes the rise of evil, as it would hurt his business. 

He has a +1 #Dagger# in his boot, and a +1 #Shortsword# under the counter.

npcs.name: Furnok of Ferd
npcs.description:
This fellow loves to gamble and he has a #Set of 7 Loaded Knucklebones#  and knows how to nick cards (this gives him a 75% probability of winning at dice, 60% of winning at cards).

His funds consist of a small hoard of gems (3750 g.p. each) and 12 each of s.p. and g.p. for gambling.

He is careful to play so as to not be caught cheating, and he makes a modest living thus, mostly skinning passing merchants.

If offered a chance to adventure, Furnok will be willing to go along for an equal share - plus all he surreptitiously lifts (particularly magic items which he covets).

To show his good faith, however, he will put up his scroll, hoping to parlay it into a more. If the worst should come, he has a +1 dagger hidden in his boot.

npcs.name: Rannos Dovi
npcs.description: The storekeeper, a ponderous figure, moved with deliberate slowness, his frame reflecting a sedentary past. Clumsy yet placid, he eyed merchandise with a languid gaze. Unbeknownst to many, his former life as a thief had evolved into a tranquil storekeeping existence, the bustling world around him a stark contrast to his past exploits.

townText:
The Village of Hommlet -- Hommlet as it is commonly called -- is situated in the central part of the Flanaess, that portion of eastern Oerik Continent which is known and "civilised". The village (actually hamlet-sized, though local parlance distinguished it with the term "village") is located some 10 or so leagues southeast of the town of Verbobonc, on the fringe of the territory controlled by its noble Lord, the Viscount of Verbobonc. 

It is at a crossroads. 

To the north is the mighty Velverdyva River, along whose south bank runs the Lowroad. Many days' travel to the east, on the shores of the Lake of Unknown Depths (Nyr Dyv) is the great walled city of Dyvers, the village of Sobanwych about halfway along the route. Below that to the southeast and east are miles and miles of forest, the Gnarley, beyond which is the Wild Coast, Wooly Bay, and the Sea of Gearnat. 

The road south forks a league or so beyond the little community, one meandering off towards the Wild Coast, the other rolling through the lower Kron Hills to the village of Ostverk and then eventually turning southwards again into the leven Kingdom of Celene. 

The western route leads into the very heart of the gnomish highlands, passing through Greenway Valley about a day's travel distant and going onwards to the Lortmil Mountains far beyond.

Hommlet grew from a farm or two, a rest house, and a smithy. The roads brought a sufficient number of travellers and merchant wagons to attracts tradesmen and artisans to serve those passing through. The rest house became a thriving inn, a wheel and wainwright settled in the thorp, and more farmers and herdsmen followed, for grain was needed for the passing animals, and meat was in demand for the innfolk.

Prosperity was great, for the lord of the district was mild and taxed but little. Trade was good, and the area was untroubled by war or outlaws or ravaging beasts. The area was too free, too beautiful, too bountiful, at least in the eyes of some.

Whether the evil came west from Dyvers as is claimed by one faction, or crept up out of the forestlands bordering the Wild Coast as others assert, come it did. At first it was only a few thieves and an odd group of bandits molesting the merchant caravans. Then came small bands of humanoids -- kobolds or goblins -- raiding the flocks and herds. Local militia and foresters of the Waldgraf and Ostverk apparently checked, but not stopped, the spread of outlawry and evil.

A collection of hovels and their slovenly inhabitants formed the nucleus for the troubles and which were to increase. A wicked cleric established a small chapel at this point. The folk of Hommlet tended to ignore Nulb, even thoug it was but six miles distant. The out-of-the-way position was ideal for the fell purposes planned for this settlement, as was its position on a small river flowing into the Velverdyva. The thickets and marshes around Nulb became the lair and hiding place for bandits, brigands, and all sorts of evil men and monsters alike. The chapel grew into a stone temple as its faithful brough in their ill-gotten tithes. 

Good folk were robbed, pillaged, enslaved, or worse. In but three years a grim and foreboding fortress surrounded the evil place, and swarms of creatures worshipped and worked their wickedness there. The servants of the Temple of Elemental Evil made Hommlet and the lands for leagues around a mockery of freedom and beauty. 

Commerce ceased, crops withered, pestilence was abroad. But the leaders of this cancer were full of hubris, and in their overweaning pride sought to overthrow the good realms of the north who were coming to the rescue of the land being crushed under the tyranny wrought by the evil temple. 

A great battle was fought to the east, and when villagers saw streams of ochre-robed men and humanoids fleeing south and west through their community, there was great rejoicing, for they knew that the murderous oppresors had been defeated and driven from the field in panic and rout.

So great was the slaughter, so complete the victory of good, that the walled stronghold of the Temple of Elemental Evil fell within a fortnight, despite the aid of a terrible demon. The place was ruined and sealed against a further return of such abominations by powerful blessings and magic. Life quickly returned to a semblance of what it had been before the rise of the temple, and in the decade since, the village and surrounidng countryside have in facet become more rich and prosperous than ever before. 

A monstrous troll which plagued the place for a time was hunted down by a body of passing adventurers. With its ashes, these fellows returuned a goodly fortune as well, leaving a portion with the villagers to repay them for their losses before going elsewhere to seek their fortunes.

Other adventurers, knowing of the evil that had once resided in the area, came to seek out similar cahces, and not a few did locate remote lairs and find wealth -- just as some never returned at all.

After some five years, adventurers stopped coming to the area, as it seemed that no monsters were left to slay, no evil existed gere to be stamped out. For four years thereafter, this seemed true, but then bandits began to ride the roads again -- not frequently, but to some effect. This seemed all too familiar somehow to the good folk of Hommlet, so they sent word to the Viscount that wicked forces might still lurk thereabouts. This informaiton has been spread throughout the countryside, and the news has attracted outsiders to the village once again. Who and what these men are, no one can be quite sure, although all claim to be bent on slaying monsters and bringing peace and security to Hommlet, for deeds speaks more loudly than words, and lies cloak true purposes of the malevolent.
